Let (S,\Sigma ,\mu ) be a measure space and let p,q\in [1,\ \infty ] with 1/p+1/q=1. Then for all measurable real- or complex-valued functions f and g on S,
\lVert fg \rVert \leq \lVert f \rVert _{p}\lVert g \rVert _{q}.
If, in addition, p,q\in (1,\ \infty ) and f\in L^{q}(\mu ) and g\in L^{q}(\mu ), then Holder's inequality becomes an equality if and only if \lVert f\rVert ^{p} and \lVert g\rVert ^{q} are linearly dependent in L^{1}(\mu ), meaning that there exist real numbers a,\,\beta \geq 0, not both of them zero, such that \lVert f\rVert ^{p}=\beta \,\lVert g\rVert ^{q} \mu -almost everywhere.
